comments.commentBody: This is just silly. My wife managed a "non-profit" medical system in Seattle for 10 years and believe me when I tell you that profit (i.e. revenue above all their costs) was always a priority. UPMC in Pittsburgh is a "non-profit" and their executives are all multi-millionaires. UPMC is constantly buying real estate , building new facilities, buying out small practices and doing anything they can to eliminate any possible competition. The only improvement to patient care and preventive services that they devote any excess revenue to is miniscule compared to their business expansion and executive compensation. The had nearly $500M left after all expenses (including improvements to patient care, etc.) last year. They are the largest employer in the state. Nursing wages are some of the lowest in the country, despite the fact that health care costs in Pittsburgh are among the highest in the country. Why? Because UPMC controls the medical labor market and the health care market in the region.

"Systems that employ doctors, modeled after well-known organizations like Kaiser Permanente, are better able to coordinate patient care and to find ways to deliver improved services at lower costs...."

The chief reason Kaiser is a model for the future of health care is that it is non-profit--there are no corporate shareholders to demand cutting corners in the name of increased shareholder dividends.

All revenues go to the improvement of patient care, especially preventive services.

I think Nokia has a quality product here with the Win 8 phones I've seen. I believe Apple is wearing down with iPhone 5, first time I've talked to several iPhone loyalists who admitted disappointment with a new iPhone. The bigger question is how committed carriers actually are. Sure they would like more competition but not if it costs them anything. Mobile markets move quickly when something is trending and even if Win phones start slow remember that Android's first 2 quarters barely reached 5% market share in 2010. 2 years later Android has over 60% which is why I wouldn't even count Blackberry totally out of it though in my opinion they have a very low chance of success or even continued operation.

In the local stores I visited there were only Black or White Lumia with only 1 store having received a Red 920, however even as I was talking to the clerk at two different stores more people came in asking about Win phones which seems way more interest than the Win 7 phones received where not even the sales people had heard about it.
Tough. Yet another reason fans shouldn't attend these overpriced games. Watch it at home.

It's a sport, not a performance art. (at least it's supposed to be a sport)

Coach Popovich is doing what he believes is in the best competitive interest of his team and his players over a long season. Stern's actions show no respect for the NBA as a sport, rather just treating it as if it were a staged performance.

In no way should a coach ever be fined and punished for honestly managing in the best competitive interests of his team and his players. Popovich gave his players a rest, and also gave his bench an opportunity to step up and develop some solid playing time which will be valuable to the competitiveness, depth, and confidence of his team the rest of the way. It's a SMART coaching move from someone who understands how players play the game.

Stern's fine is absurd.

I dunno. The NBA players a paid a lot to provide entertainment on a well-established schedule, and fans pay pretty hefty prices for tickets. If you were a big Tim Duncan or Manu Ginobli fan who'd happened to be able to catch a game in Miami, wouldn't you feel a bit cheated by Popovich's action?
I'm with you, Jack.  Well said.

Stern's NBA is all about showcasing "superstars", and NOTHING about the game. It's all spectacle and no sport. Stern continues to expose his league as a fraud and a sham. Did he only care that the players be in the stadium for the game? Or would he require that they play cameo minutes? Does he have a secret minimum number of minutes in mind? Would he call plays for Duncan?

I don't care much about the NBA anymore, but I get surprised at how stupid Stern can be. He has had too much power for too long. The owners should fire him.

I may be missing something, but I've often attended the final game of the season and if it involved one or more play-off teams and the outcome could not alter their status in a meaningful way, they invariably rested key players.  Is it Stern's position that this universal practice is unethical and inimical to the interests of the NBA and it short-changes the fans?  If so, he should have dealt with it years ago.  If not, his sanctions against the Spurs are profoundly mistaken, if not ouright hypocritical.  I guess we'll see what he does in April.
The policy Stern invoked is absurd, autocratic, and decidedly un-American.

Stern has done a lot for the NBA.  However, he has overstepped his role on this issue.  He does not own the Spurs and the coach does not work for Stern.  Popovich made a decision, as a coach that underscores why he is respected as a coach - he is looking out for his team and team members.  I imagine people who purchased tickets in Miami to see the game were looking forward to see the top players from San Antonio play against the Miami Heat.  From that perspective one can understand Stern's view.   Nevertheless the NBA season is a long season and Popovich made a solid rational decision for which he should not be penalized.
Why any of us are paying the kind of money required for major sports events is beyond me, but that's a different column!

I think the concern is that all these players were given the same game off, depriving the fans of seeing any of the star players.  If one player had the night off, I don't think this would have been an issue.  I do understand Mr. Stern's objections here.  To take the baseball analogy, if Derek Jeter gets a day off, no worries.  If Jeter, Teixeira, Cano, Granderson, Rodriguez, and Rivera all don't come to the park, the fans are going to feel ripped off.  The NBA has a product to sell, and in this case they shortchanged the fans who payed good money for a big matchup.

It's clearly time for David Stern to issue financial sanctions against himself for embarrassing the NBA with his dictatorial lunacy in this situation. Would Popovich have been okay to sue the league for damages if two of his aging veteran stars had been injured while playing in their 5th road game in 8 days? Actually  the real embarrassment for Stern comes from the fact that the Spurs were within a point of the NBA champion Heat with 13 seconds to go in the game. Maybe Popovich, 4 time NBA champion coach, reasonably thought the Spurs would be better served by his coaching decision to play fresh players for this road game against the Heat - a COACHING decision that Stern should have nothing to say about.

The Nanny State strikes again! Commissioners have to act like they are doing something. Thus, stupid intrusions into a private decision. This was the Spurs wanting to win, their way. Who is Stern to say otherwise?

No one should delude him/herself with the idea that David Stern functions accordingly to some sort of altruistic passion for basketball. If were not for his love of money, he wouldn’t have become what I considered to be one of the major scoundrels of sports, the blessed capitalist pope of basketball, who ultimately serves profit and no one else. The players’ overly used bodies, mental wellness, and family life, have not been central to Stern’s managerial work. The multi-billionaire contracts with TV channels, and the advertisement industry, the increase in the market-value of every team in the league, and the commissioner’s self image as a savvy businessmen, lover of sports, and philanthropist, underpinned every one of Stern’s move since 1968. Pope Stern’s latest punitive decision against the Spurs in his usual authoritarian fashion, is just another episode in the life o this legally “legitimate” Mafioso of modern elite sporting in the U.S.

The megalomania of David Stern continues. You can almost hear echoes of the five year old Stern: "If you won't play with me, I'll get even somehow. Just watch me!"

This is one more reminder of how Stern has made the league all about his majesty. Remember when you were kicking yourself because there was no NBA on TV and Bernard King went for 52 last night? Bird? Magic? Who knew that those were the days.
So true!
In professional sports, players are treated like disposable assets. I really doubt that "the best interests of the NBA" are the same as the best interests of basketball.

I think many of the people sounding off against Stern have no idea of what the NBA was like until he came along, which kind of reflects the disrespectful  ilk the last 2 generations have been breeding. What he does, he does on behalf of what the fans pay their money to see. He obviously should reconsider scheduling of games so that the players don't become mere circus animals on beck and call. I still side with Pop for watching out for his players. I dissgree with Stern dishing out penalties like this, spontaneously. But that doesn't mean I don't know who.s responsible for the growth and marketing of the NBA the last 2 1/2 decades, it's offcourt NBA based charities and player/public community bonding. as well as, programs to help rookies manage thier money and their lives. It's better the owners sit down with him rather than people just trashing him.

You are not thinking this through very well.  "A couple of hours of work" for you is not the same as a "couple of hours" of peak, world-class athletic performance (no offense).  Especially in basketball with lots of short starts and stops, changes of direction, twists and high jumps. It is very tough on the joints and one of the reasons professional athletes get arthritis much earlier than "civilians".  It is ridiculous to schedule games that tightly, and Stern is the one at fault here.  He should not be surprised at the pushback.

This is a finely coddled egg. Let's see, you only work a fraction of the year. You don't work every day and you are paid millions of dollars to work for a couple of hours when you do. Then the boss feels bad when you have had to work for five days and gives you a night off. Too bad for the people who don't make millions who paid to see you play. To bad we can't pay actors on broadway that kind of money for doing eight shows a week. I think this is a wonderful opportunity to take our deification and indulgence of star athletes to a new level. I shudder to think how they survived on a commercial airline. I hope they have all started a prophylactic course of Zithromax and Diflucan.

The NBA owes David Stern a large debt of appreciation for the good work he did early in his tenure to popularize the league and build revenues. Unfortunately he is calling in that debt in very unfortunate ways. This heavy-handed abuse of Popovich and the Spurs is just the latest example.

As has been said before, David Stern has overstayed his welcome.

Morris did not seriously contribute to either of Toronto's World Series victories. In 1992, he went 0-2 with an 8.44 era in the World Series. In 1993, he didn't pitch in the post-season at all, and he had an awful 6.19 era during the regular season.

Being on 4 teams that won the World Series is meaningless as a standard, unless you also want to put someone like Ken Holtzman in the Hall of Fame. He was on 5 World Series winners.

Bryan, Holtzman is a bad comparison to Morris. Morris was the ace of his teams for most of the years he played. Holtzman won only 3 world series and all underneath the A's surrounded by HoF's Pitchers Catfish Hunter and Rollie Fingers plus HOF Reggie Jackson. No pitcher from any of the teams are in from the years Morris won. Also Holtzman only one with one team Morris did it with three different teams a major league record. So wherever Morris went his attitude for winning rubbed off on his teammates.  Listen to interviews of managers from that era who coached him they all said Morris attitude for wanting to win and working hard rubbed off on all the pitchers in the Bullpen and he made those pitchers better.

Here is the thing to remember about Jack Morris he won a World Series ring in Detroit, Minnesota, and 2 in Toronto. Which qualifies Morris as a player who won the most world series rings with different teams. Starting Pitchers voted into the Hall of Fame last 80's til today by BBWAA World Series Rings
Blyleven - 2
N.Ryan - 1
D.Sutton - 0
Niekro - 0
Carlton - 2
Seaver - 1
Perry - 0
Jenkins - 0
Palmer - 3
Hunter - 5
Drysdale - 3
Marichal - 0
Gibson - 2
So at 4 WS rings he has won more than anyone voted in except Hunter in since the 80's. Morris was the winningest pitcher of the 80's outdoing Steib by 20. It should also be pointed out that in the 80's pitching numbers for pitchers in general were bad. Morris had 14 consecutive opening day starts that is reserved for the best pitcher on the team. 5 time all star. 1 time World Series MVP. Refusing to let himself go out in Game 7 and pitching a shutout that allowed that team to win the World Series possibly the greatest moment in the World Series in the last 25 years. If he played for bigger market teams like Boston Red Sox, Chicago Cubs, and Chicago White Sox did what he did he would already be in. Voters are notoriously harder on players who played for small market teams. His stats may not be the greatest out of players in, but his accomplishments are better than over half the pitcher in the Hall and clearly say Jack Morris is Hall of Fame worthy.

To champion88:

In my opinion the Republicans had a decent candidate this year, and they still lost. Part of the reason for the loss was the many Republicans who refused to vote for Romney because he is a Mormon, or because he isn't conservative enough to suit them, or because of perceived slights to the Paul camp, or because of any of the numerous other reasons they had for not voting in this election. If the same attitude exists in the Republican camp in 2016 as existed this year, I see no reason to expect anything other than another loss. Too many Republicans fail to understand that perfect, meaning in this case their idea of perfect, is the enemy of good.

Please, get a grip...independent MD's have been seeing there reimbursement drop consistently over the last decade, they are basically told by Medicare what they will make, and private insurers reduce their payments to match. There is virtually no way that an independent private practice doctor's office can survive this climate of decreasing professional reimbursement while their expenses inexorably keep rising (facility costs, personel all want raises, equipment and supply increases).

Those skimming out all the $ from this health care debacle are the MBA/executive/administrative-contribute-nothing-to-patient-health-types, extracting the last dime from every "consumer-provider" (formerly patient-docter) "transaction"...they will bleed the systme dry, while leaving the true providers of care (MD, nurse, PA, NP, etc) high and dry....and liable for all the legal action for following the "corporate health" mandated template...

Shocking, shocking, shocking that a hospital or other medical care provider would make decisions and force people to act in a way that maximizes their profits.  Just shocking.  Unfortunately also true.  Our system must change.

I am a primary care NP. When I was looking for my first job, I was warned about working for a hospital system by a physician who had just left such a job. He told me how each month, he had a meeting in which his referrals were detailed to him. For each referral he made outside the hospital system, he had to explain himself. "That doctor is the best cardiologist for this patient" was not an acceptable explanation. This doctor told me that hospital systems routinely lose money on the actual primary care practice, with the understanding that the providers in the practice will generate a lot of revenue for the hospital by recommending specialists, radiology tests, surgery, etc. within the system. I was shocked, as I was quite naive about this system. Needless to say, I didn't apply for any jobs in a hospital system.

I have admired and commented on your avatar / icon before.  Today, Caravaggio's "David with the Head of Goliath," a favourite painting from my favourite painter, truly hits the mark. Republicans need stop their empty posturing, honorably accept defeat and get to work.
You sure about that?

I have admired and commented on your avatar / icon before. Today, Caravaggio's "David with the Head of Goliath," a favourite painting from my favourite painter, truly hits the mark. Republicans need stop their empty posturing, honorably accept defeat and get to work.

I for one am willing to dance off the Fiscal Cliff if it means confronting the shameful brand of politics played by these Republicans. The Administration has every right to ensure the same tools of blackmail don't hang above its head for the remainder of its duration.

I think we can see now that even a second electoral victory for Obama hasn't been sufficient to shrug at least some of the silliness of these Republicans, and so we must hold steady and firm.

Exactly Julie, anecdotal evidence by the NYT.

It is much easier designing a website than designing an iPad. How many Electrical Engineers does Apple have that are college drop-outs. I would bet zero, considering the difficultly of the discipline.

Hear, hear!
In college, among many other things, you get to hone your own mind by meeting and interacting with people who are very different from yourself.
Not likely to happen when you decide to start your own company instead.
I bet those geniuses the article lists can't really discuss too many subjects outside of their own area of expertise.

Also, here successful means successful in business and money.  Reading Jobs biography makes me wonder how successful he was, ultimately, with others in his life.  Could his personal and business relationships been better if he had taken college classes to make him a more well rounded person?  Maybe some sociology and psychology classes would have helped him get more out of his relationships, and made him a more compassionate human being.

These articles always list Gates, Jobs, Dell and Zuckerberg. A handful of dropouts who have been wildly successful. Compare that to the much larger list of college graduates who have started successful companies. If you're extremely talented, you don't need a college degree. Unfortunately, most people are not extremely talented.

I disagree. Most physicians sell their practices largely because of the incredible hassles of dealing with insurance companies and related administrative demands of private practice. They assume it will be easier to practice medicine when the hospital takes over the administrative burdens. Money is part of it but not most of it.

I have had bad professors, too. But I've had wonderful ones as well, some of whom I keep in touch with. Some taught me 30 years ago, and I can still hear them saying the things that had a profound influence on my life. It is those types of professors that I try to emulate when I teach.

The typical example in the article is the person who learns everything on their own. A professor I had at Michigan told a grad school class that he would not cover "everything" in class but he still expected everyone to know the things not covered. He immediately added "don't worry; you wouldn't be grad students if you hadn't shown that you can learn everything on your own." Was that his opinion of Stanford, where he got his bachelor's, master's and Ph.D.? In contrast, I had a History professor complain during his first semester at Michigan that no students were coming to his office hours to talk like they had at the small college he came from. Why bother? We were conditioned to learn on our own.

I've had professors teaching classes on subjects that they never learned as a student and admit to me to having a poor understanding of the material. I've had professors that went so slow I had to drop the course or switch sections. I've had professors do nothing more than open a textbook and read from it while writing formulas on the blackboard (never once turning to look at the class). And I've had textbooks that were nothing more than pure "rote" learners; no explanations, no context and nothing but pure "plug-n-chug" through the mathematical techniques: rote learning.

In contrast, even though finding a "good" teacher in college is like finding a needle in a haystack, I did find some, like others have. You wind up taking all of their courses, even their PhD courses.
